text: Case sensitive.
Hah!
hyrdoid vs hydroid
I honestly still feel like it is, despite all the evidence showing me that I'm clearly wrong.
I mean, 4 mana for 1 card and 1 life is not worth, 6 mana for 2 mana and 2 cards and a 4/4 flample is okay I guess, but really it doesn't do anything gamebreaking until you hit 8+

And in a format that has [[Spawn of Mayhem]], Aurelia, [[Demonlord Belzenlok]], [[Demon of Catastrophes]], [[Doom Whisperer]], and [[Rakdos, the Showstopper]] with duals that allow you to play any color without any drawback besides your wallet...

text: It's not like Flample is special.
It's not like simic can get up to 8 mana... oh wait
Sure, I suppose.
simic decks are more than usually likely to cast it at instant speed, more likely to get more than X +1/+1 counters, and more likely to be able to convert those +1/+1 counters into something else

You’re missing the point - it’s a scalable card that let’s you sink your mana into it while also giving you a blocker and life/card advantage early. You can recur it in Sultai and dump more mana into it late game. The killer part of the design is it’s a straight X-spell vs. XX - that was just what they added on for the cast trigger bonus.
Are we talking about the Krasis in terms of standard and it’s current price or EDH?
I’m talking in terms of Standard, which was the review’s context.
Thanks.
i was thinking simic commanders

Again, I fully understand that I'm wrong on this. I'm just saying that I still don't understand why. It's great that you can play it early, mid, or late, but it's still underwhelming in all but one of those categories.
Do you play standard, <@UEF135G05> ?
I’m not sure I understand why you think that it’s underwhelming in any of those situations.
As a rule, no.
Which is why I'm more than comfortable explaining my ignorance. = )
Ok, then I understand a bit where you’re coming from.

Also, I don’t play Standard, but I do tend to read and consume a lot to have a cursory understanding.

I haven’t read much about the Krasis, but I’ll use another card as an example that I’ve read a bit about: [[Basilica Bell Haunt]]

text:
This card is starting to pick up in play in Standard despite looking the “worst” of the cycle at times, but it’s seeing play because of a number of factors.
1) decks that can play it (ie, BWx decks) exist in the format. So, before anything else, it has a home that it can exist in.

2) it provides “advantage” in three forms. With its discard clause, it’s always trading with at least a card. Also, because of its body, it blocks aggressive strategies well, and 3 life on top of it is a very good buffer.

3.) the meta around it allows it to be functional.

I’d say, without knowing actual details, that the Krasis likely falls into several of these categories as well. It gains life and draws a card regardless when you cast it, and it comes with an evasive body. These things tend to add up to a greater sum in standard than they do in Commander.
Fair enough, I suppose.

Looking at SCG, it looks that Krasis is being played currently in Sultai midrange, ie a deck that wants to grind out advantages over the length of a game. Krasis gives a scaling threat over the course of the game, and the longer the game goes, the stronger the Krasis, and therefore the deck, becomes.
and in that deck, if Krasis is killed early, it can be regrown and cast for more mana later for further advantage, etc.

Yes, Krasis is a value engine where it pushes the deck over the top in the mid to late game. The cast trigger vs ETB makes it absolutely wild. What Mason said is very true, it allows decks to 1 for 1 and then refuel for a push to close out the game, which in this first round of tournaments is very powerful. It let the decks playing it know it was ok to expend resources to keep the aggro decks from pulling away as well as not having to worry about the control decks getting too many x-for-1's. I know you say flample isn't a big deal, but in Standard it's a huge deal since all the other fliers are usually going to be smaller with the exception of an adapted Pteramander or a juicy Crackling Drake, which still only has 4 toughness regardless of power. The card is very very good right now. That might shift, but for an opening weekend tournament, it was kind of the perfect card
Are we talking about just standard or edh too

The biggest difference between 60-card formats and Commander is resource accumulation in EDH vs resource management in 60-card decks. Understanding and appreciating the difference is the biggest gap I see when players from either format try to evaluate cards for the ones they don't play
Standard. That was the point of contention on not understanding why the card was so good for standard but not for EDH
Commander there are definitely more efficient draw engines, but this one filling so many different roles makes it incredibly powerful for 60-card formats
Tempo hits are radically better in 60-card too
Which is resource management I guess
Vapor Snag is the perfect example of that. forgettable in EDH, all star in Legacy
It's why Sphinx's Rev was backbreaking in standard and meh in EDH

Folks opinion of land destruction is very telling of this point. Folks don't appreciate you playing Cataclysm in EDH because they spent so much time effort accumulating resources. 60-card(and 40-cards) decks...you shrug and say "yep, that's understandable"
I really like the way you put it on the cast a while back, matt. 60 card is about resource allocation, commander is just resource accumulation
Yup
I can't take credit for that term, but I'll repeat it because it's 100% true
I personally wouldn't use the card in edh unless the deck is built around infinite.
is it the nature of 60 card vs 100, or is it 1v1 vs 4-player?
If I drew off the counters, simic counter abuse... but it's off cast? Meh
60 card formats are inherently 1v1, so you can say 1v1 vs 4player and use it interchangable w/ "60" and "100"
no
those are separate design elements
Looking at subpar draw, life and creature. You can say it's good value for an all in one card but.. itll be a poor blocker and a large sink for little cards
1v1 commander games are played. 4-player brawl games are played. i suggest that "60 card" is semantically the wrong term, when you really mean "more than 2 players"
or the opposite of that
whatev
e.g. "Tempo hits are radically better in 1v1" is true whether the deck is 60 cards or 100
end pedantic mode
I think krasis is fine only in Animar, where it scales the same way it would in standard.

Yeah, they are two different axis I think. Tempo hits are a big deal like Nate said in 1v1 no matter the card count. Conversely you have things like filtering which is a bigger deal in 60 card than 100 card. Though that specific example also may be in part due to singleton vs 4-of.
So three axis maybe? Singleton vs. 4-of, mulitplayer vs 1v1, and 100 card vs 60?
ya singleton is another axis

e.g. "Mill is better in 60 vs 100" is true bc decks are smaller. "Mill is better is 1v1 vs 4p" is also true bc more mill cards say 'target' than 'each' (opponent). Same result, but different reasons. "Mill is better is 4-of vs singleton" is true bc you can use more of the each cards if multiplayer.
4-of formats look for a few of the highest quality cards for a strategy, while singleton formats need a deeper bench of cards
some strats have deeper benches than others
Over 500 votes on Facebook for the damn sportsball poll.
Eh?
Hey HEEEEY, help me prove a point, is [[!maze of ith]] a "removal" card?
For tokens, maybe.
I’d say no.
Why for tokens?
Oh, thinking of the newer one that actually exiles.
[[!mystifying maze]]?
No it isn’t.
[[Thaumatic Compass]]
And [[Spires of Orazca]]
